I ended up finding 2 great pairs of pants, some really cool shoes and boots, and a cute pair of earrings. The prices were good, and I was pleased overall. It is like shopping at Marshalls or TJ Maxx.. you just need to have enough time to sift through all the racks before you come across some really good finds!

attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 2, 'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': True, 'valet': False}, 'BikeParking': True, 'WheelchairAccessible': True}
name: Marshalls
text: This is a great Marshall's -- with everything from super ladies shoes to soaps to housewares and great clothes, this store has an awesome selection of everything!  When the holidays roll around, this is a great place to search for great gifts for everyone on your list.

name: Jesse Brown's Adventure
text: Great little shop with a nice variety of  clothing, shoes, camping gear, etc.  Whether you are into fly fishing or snowboarding, they can help outfit you for the geat outdoors!Of course, this shop isn't as large as their main store across from Southpark, but if you need something that they don't have in stock here, they're happy to get it for you.   I like REI, but it is nice to support the "little guy" when you can...so you should check these guys out!

attributes: {'WiFi': 'free'}
name: Charlotte Mecklenburg Library - Myers Park
text: Behold the library. I'm not that old. In demographer terms I'm a millennial. But I did start going to school before cell phones could fit in a pocket, much less a bag. Naturally, the internet wasn't a thing and I typed my earliest reports on an electric typewriter. Our first computer had a tube screen and a dot matrix printer that used accordioned paper with perforated edges you could tear off. When I did reports, I went to the library to find books for research. In high school, as the internet became a thing my teachers clutched with false-hopes to their demands that we cite actual books. By the time I made it to college, internet catalogs like JSTOR, where you can find most scholarly articles at your fingertips in the comfort of your own dorm room or home, were the in-thing.I came to Charlotte for college and used the UNCC library extensively when I couldn't find a good source on JSTOR. That's a wonderful library. Because of it, I never had the need to sign up for the Mecklenburg County library system. After graduating, my need for a library was gone. I joined the working world and never looked back. Seven years later my interest in reading rekindled and I started having the insatiable desire to stick my nose in a book. In walks the CMECK Library.Now that I've finished my personal life story, I'll tell you about this library. It's the location of choice where I signed up to start my new membership. Located right off the "Booty Loop", a popular cyclist riding spot, I pass it frequently. It's a super convenient location in a relatively walkable or bikeable area. Outside there's a cute garden greeting you as you walk in the door. Inside the door there's a rack of magazines and newspapers like Endurance and Creative Loafing. On the counter you can find a regularly updated list of the top NY times best sellers. Across from the desk you can find many of these best sellers and other popular books on two small shelves alongside the most recent DVD releases.For the newer DVDs there is a very small rental fee of $2 that covers a few days. Still better than RedBox if you ask me. Older DVDs come free of charge and we've been using this to rewatch Star Wars. There are computers available, some desks to work at and comfy chairs to sit in and read. Space is quite limited as this is a very small branch library. The selection is also limited but there are still a lot of books coming from a guy who hasn't been in a library in years. The Nonfiction is organized by subject (using call numbers) which is a bit confusing to a newcomer like me. The Fiction is organized by author last name. There is a young adult section and on the far back side of the library a children's section with ample toys. There are even doors here - lots of good thinkin' went into the design to keep as much noise as possible out of the main area.I use the library's online holds and lists system to keep track of and rate what I've read. It's worlds above what amazon offers for the same. (They tend to favor trying to get you to buy stuff.) The manager of this branch helped me find my way and understand the call number system. She was incredibly considerate, being that I knew jack-diddly! She was actually happy to guide me through, saying she doesn't get to do that often. There are also plenty of opportunities to volunteer. Though small, this library feels very cozy and like a hidden gem. Every time I come buy I feel like I'm in a sanctuary of fantasy that can pull me out of the stress of the real world. Yeah I'll say it, it's like getting lost in a book. Literally.

attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 2, 'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': True, 'valet': False}, 'BikeParking': True}
name: Charlotte Re-Cyclery
text: I see it's been almost a year since the ReCyclery had its last review. Honestly it's a shame they don't have more reviews considering they've been here for over 10 years now! I just recently got acquainted with the place but I love it so I'm gonna share the love.One thing Yelp seems to refuse to add even though I've already tried to add it is the category "non-profit organizations". You see, Trips for Kids and the ReCyclery are technically two separate entities. Trips for Kids itself is a not-for-profit organization with "chapters" around the country dedicated strictly to community outreach teaching kids to ride and getting them interested in bikes while at the same time leading "Earn-A-Bike" programs through which they encourage good behavior and grades in school by rewarding students with bikes. And honestly speaking I have no direct personal experience with the Trips for Kids - I ain't got no kids myself and they tend to be annoying little buggers.The ReCyclery on the other hand is the not-for-profit business through which Trips for Kids is supported. Here they repair and refurbish old donated bicycles and resell them or provide them to the Trips for Kids programs. Any "profit" is used to pay the few employees, pay for operating costs and put back into the programs. Volunteering is open to pretty much anyone, but you are required to take their introductory class. Volunteers get to use their time as credit to purchase anything from the shop.On the topic of the shop, they've got an excellent friendly crowd of what I like to call "bicycle engineers". Most of the team can tell you anything that's wrong with your bike and get it fixed or replaced in a jiffy. Granted they all spend most of their time here working on bikes non-stop. You can buy any kind of bike here or just buy the parts if you prefer to do the work yourself. You have the opportunity to have your bike repaired with reused/recycled parts or new ones. And you can be certain that the work is done well. Most adult bikes here seem to average in the mid-$200s. Which frankly is awesome for what you get. A fully overhauled bike with new tubes, tires, chain, break and shifter cables, etc. re-greased and fine-tuned oftentimes even better than new. And you will often see relatively nice frames from good brands too (Trek, Surly, Raleigh, etc.).I've heard some staff here can be fairly "unhelpful" but you will have to bear in mind that half of the folks working here most days are volunteers and don't have the permissions to run payments. A lot of them are also more interested in coming in and working on bikes it seems. My advice: when you come in just don't be afraid to speak up and announce yourself and say what you're looking for. There can often be a sense of disarray in here with people all off in their own little worlds at the bike stands.

attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 3, 'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': True, 'validated': False, 'lot': False, 'valet': False}, 'BikeParking': True}
name: lululemon athletica
text: I am thoroughly impressed with Lulu Lemon. I've avoided the place for a while now simply because of the outrageous prices. Yes, let's fess up, the prices are outrageous. I've been told more than once by a friend of mine that they don't want to pay $70 for a pair of yoga shorts that are just gonna get dirty and sweaty. That said, here's my review.I started off slow with Lulu Lemon. First off, I had just heard they set up shop in Birkdale so I had to stop in just because. Also, I'm a regular runner these days so I thought why not check out some more fashionable workout wear? I went in, looked around and was pretty well impressed with the style and options. If you're the kinda guy or girl that likes to spend most of your day in comfy athletic gear, this is a place you'd probably want to frequent. However, as I said, I started off slow. I was impressed with their "silver" line. They weave silver thread through all manner of clothing to help cut down on microbes and their respective odors. I bought a pair of socks ($18) with this technology. They are excellent for running. Keep your feet cool, dry and comfy. I now have 3 pair. Yes, I agree the price is high but I also feel it's worth it.I decided to graduate to a nice pair of shorts next. I was pretty impressed with the Surge shorts and the Pacebreaker shorts. I settled on the Pacebreaker H2O because it was pitched as an "everything" short. Studio (yoga), gym and beach ready. I liked the concept and I think they would make great swimming trunks, but they ended up being horrible for running and for yoga. Of all things, yoga. That's right, even with the neat little Lulu Lemon logo on them, they did not excel at doing what the brand is known best for. They bound up in the legs making it difficult to really get that true stretch. So, I got in contact with their customer service folks and shared my thoughts. They were stellar, to say the least. Despite me having trial tested them, they took the shorts back and I switched to the Surge shorts which are shorter and not at all binding. I suspect they will be perfect for running and yoga and could even be used at the beach in times of need.The point in me writing this long winded review is that while I'm not a huge fan of the prices at Lulu Lemon, I am happy to find that the quality and the service are a reflection of that pricing. I would tell anyone, even the hesitant folks, to give it a try. You may be as impressed as I was.

attributes: {'DogsAllowed': True, 'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': True, 'valet': False}, 'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 2, 'BikeParking': True, 'ByAppointmentOnly': False, 'WheelchairAccessible': True}
categories: ['Bookstores', 'Flowers & Gifts', 'Cards & Stationery', 'Shopping', 'Event Planning & Services', 'Books', 'Mags', 'Music & Video', 'Gift Shops', 'Arts & Crafts', 'Jewelry']
name: Paper Skyscraper
text: Wait wait I thought I had already reviewed Paper Skyscraper?! Well it's certainly been a long time coming. All I can say is love it! They've got all the knick-knacks imaginable in this world. Excellent joke gifts like bottle openers mounted on wood with a painting of the crotch of a naked man or woman. Plenty of those items you never knew you needed like a bottle opener that looks like a skeleton key or spoons that nest together with magnets and stand upright on your countertop. Who'd a thunk it?!If you are looking for a book of inspirational ideas on architecture and interior design, this is the place to find it. And no place better than in the architecturally significant Dilworth neighborhood. Plenty of candles and wall hangings, kitchen wares, sake cups, flasks, beer bottle coozies, Charlotte paintings and memorabilia, travel items, tons of gift cards and gift wrap and stationery items. It's hard to classify this place specifically but it's essentially a gift shop. My favorite item would have to be the Buddha board thing where you can practice calligraphy with just water and a brush. The slate-based board air dries and you can write again after. The perfect example of non-attachment in Zen.I like to take travelers through the great city of Charlotte by here to pick up some post cards and such or if they're just looking for something fun and interesting. It's most assuredly worth a stop by!

attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 4, 'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': False, 'valet': False}}
name: The Salvation Army
text: Much like other second-hand, used goods stores such as Goodwill or ReStore this Salvation Army shop has some interesting finds to be had. I will say however their shop is much better laid out, larger and less cluttered. Prices are decent and comparable to the Goodwill store down the street. It's always worth it to peruse the shelves of such stores because you never know what you could find for cheap compared to the price bran new. And of course it's always good to reuse than to buy new in my opinion.The store is run by some friendly and helpful staff with an all around positive attitude in general. One of the most interesting things I saw here though was the "War Cry" publication of the Salvation Army which takes on a theme changing its entire layout every time a new issue comes out. They really take the word army in their name seriously and you don't realize it til you see this. Nonetheless they do a good job of being there without being over-the-top, in your face about their beliefs and yours.

attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 2, 'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': True, 'valet': False}, 'BikeParking': True}
name: Old Navy - Northcrest
text: Old Navy never seems to know what they're doing. Seems like every time I go in the store, this one in particular, they are in a perpetual state of entropic disorganization. You can never really find the alternative sizes for a shirt you like because they're all in mixed piles on tabletops. It's also as if they are constantly remodeling. In particular you can always be sure to find that the men's section has shrunk a little more each time you visit. I have never once come in here to find it perfectly organized.That said, I can still award Old Navy 3 stars. While the clothes aren't top quality, they still manage to have a decent variety of menswear squeezed into what little bit of area remains. Lately I noticed they've got a lot of shirts that emphasize "going outside" and nature and such. It seems to be the trend these days, at least for me. Though that won't change my dislike for "shirts with words on them". And if you're in that boat with me, you will be delighted to find that ON has a great selection of both patterned and plain shirts to be had. This includes my personal favorite: heather. You know that sort of washed out/textured look that is added to make a single color shirt look more complex. I love that design and Old Navy has it on lock. Another personal favorite of mine here is the selection of work-out-wear for men. Lots of color, lots of visibility and reflectivity and actually a dash of style that is on the level of H&M for men's work out gear.Be aware that their clothes all seem to run large and short and they absolutely do shrink in the dryer. Recently I've found that the necks in the shirts tend to stretch out a bit more than they used to. Seems that what little quality they had left is starting to go too. They also appear to struggle with speed and quality of service both on the floor and at the register.

attributes: {'BusinessParking': {'garage': True, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': False, 'valet': False}, 'Caters': False, 'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 2, 'BikeParking': True, 'RestaurantTakeOut': False, 'WheelchairAccessible': True}
name: Trader Joe's
text: Gotta love Midtown Trader Joe's! Trader Joe's doesn't get enough hype in the real world honestly. Almost everything they sell is their "house brand". But that doesn't mean it's any less delicious. I love the fresh fruits and vegetables here - they certainly pay more mind to it than most other stores. I'm also in love with the assault of pleasant scents that greets you from their huge selection of fresh flowers and herbs.Seems like they always have free samples of something that makes you absolutely want to buy it including the occasional in-store wine tastings. I am practically in love with their pre-made, bagged pizza doughs. There is regular bread, whole wheat and a garlic herb kind which is sure to make your kitchen smell like it came right out of Italy. There are lots of unique frozen foods to choose from, trail mixes and nuts, cheeses and meats and even beer both from Trader Joe's and from other breweries. You can mix and match bottles to build your own six-pack.The check outs are anything but modern and ordinary. Which is certainly not a bad thing! It's basically an experience to ring up here. The staff has a completely different, friendly demeanor about them which makes for a more homegrown kind of experience. Want to chat about what you're buying, what reusable bags you brought or even what you're wearing? Seems like someone's always ready to talk. Trader Joe's, despite being a national chain, does a good job of making itself feel local wherever you may find a store.

attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 2, 'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': False, 'valet': False}, 'BikeParking': False}
name: Aldo Shoes
text: Yo yo I wanna give a shout out to my favorite Aldo location! No for real though it is my favorite location. The staff is excellent, the store manager is friendly and helpful and they always have the newest trending styles here before any other location gets them. The only reason I don't come here more often is because I live pretty dang far away.Lately I've not been overly impressed with their selection. They do have a few nice pairs of boots as we come into the colder seasons but for men I find the casual shoe selection kinda drab. Maybe I'm showing my age? Hahaha! Also, when money is tight, the chance of me buying $80-$150 shoes goes way down. The jewelry, ties and scarves are always great though. And more manageable in price. But across the board I've been happy with whatever I've purchased at Aldo.

attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True}
categories: ['Motorcycle Gear', 'Auto Repair', 'Car Dealers', 'Auto Parts & Supplies', 'Motorcycle Dealers', 'Automotive', 'Auto Loan Providers', 'Shopping']
name: Kevin Powell MotorSports Charlotte
text: I have nothing but praise for this place. I've been bicycle obsessed all my life. It figures it was only natural to eventually want something I don't have to pedal. So I found myself in a beautiful Triumph Bonneville but lacking proper knowledge and gear. I initially only came here out of convenience but I haven't stopped coming back. They've shared plenty of advice and suggestions from day one so why not?I bought my first helmet, jacket and riding gloves here. (Still gotta get the time to come back and pick out pants.) Staff has always been helpful in finding me a size and best fit for my comfort and preferences. They're all also riders which makes them great sources of real-life experience-based suggestions. On the price side, I guess they're reasonable. Considering I have no prior experience buying riding gear I can't say for sure. But helmets run the gambit from under $100 (Skorpion, etc.) up to several several hundred dollars (Arai, Shoei, etc.). Jackets too, depending on brand and features. I got mine for around $150 but they go down to low $100s and up to several hundred. There are more gloves than you can wrap your brain around, much less your fingers! $30~$80 roughly.Lots of motorcycles also for sale here. US and Japanese bikes alike. I don't remember seeing any European brands though granted I wasn't really looking for them. There are so many bikes and ATVs and such that the store is packed to the brim and practically spilling over onto the front sidewalk. I don't have experience with their shop but I know they don't do body work as they directed me to another place for it when I asked. I imagine I would take my bike here for other work if need be so maybe I can write to that later.In short, love this place and will continue to come back!

attributes: {'DogsAllowed': True, 'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': True, 'valet': False}, 'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 2, 'BusinessAcceptsBitcoin': False, 'BikeParking': True, 'WheelchairAccessible': True}
name: Parker Banner Kent & Wayne
text: The one game that grabbed my attention was the the table-top card game Magic the Gathering (MtG). They have everything imaginable for this all time greatest of card games. You can find singles from about every set out there plus boosters and decks for the newest sets. MtG has come a long way and this place does a good job of keeping it going.Every night is a game night here and half the store is actually not a store but is rather devoted to rows upon rows of tables for gaming. They of course do tons of other card games including Pokemon and Yu-Gi-Oh to name a few. And of course Dungeons and Dragons and figure/landscape based games like Warhammer. On the side that belongs to the store they have plenty of gaming accessories: dice, paints, landscape and figure pieces, deck and card boxes and sleeves and much more. Not to mention they have an extensive collection of comics including plenty most of us have never even heard of. Last but certainly not least, they've got a couple of shelf-fulls of unusual indie-made board games. These things are perhaps the most intriguing, encompassing any number of unthought-of or simply out-there genres.The staff is great by the way. They are all of course very much into the subject matter. They were very inspiring to me, often talking me into getting back into the fun game of Magic the Gathering and coming back on the regular. I'm sure the folks here are always on the look out for some new blokes to beat up on with their awesome deck builds. But I'm always sure to go back!

attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 2, 'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': False, 'valet': False}, 'BikeParking': False}
categories: ['Department Stores', "Men's Clothing", 'Swimwear', "Women's Clothing", 'Shopping', 'Shoe Stores', 'Fashion', 'Home Decor', 'Home & Garden']
name: Kohl's
text: There was a little confusion about where exactly this new Kohl's department store was located.  The address is 601 Sherman Place in Waxhaw, NC, but it wasn't even on Google Maps.  Turns out this isn't technically in Waxhaw.  It's in unincorporated Union County served by the Waxhaw post office; hence the Waxhaw address (much like Indian Land which is 100% unincorporated but uses Fort Mill's post office so they use Fort Mill as the city in their addresses too).  Anyhoo, this is actually at the Southeast corner of Tom Short and Rea Rd, a mile or two south of Blakeney.  It's the spot where Walmart wanted to build a store for years, but they ended up two feet from Ballantyne yet in SC.  I't still somewhat rural out here, but there is a lot of suburban sprawl like most other places, hence the need for places like this.  It's a big store, but is only one floor.  There is plenty of parking.  It was busy yesterday but there were still plenty of spaces - none of which are too far away from the store.It's Kohl's, so they have some awesome deals, especially if you use the Kohl's charge, plus they had some killer grand opening specials.  They are also open until 11 pm for their grand opening but that will change soon.  While the Kohl's in Rock Hill is closer to me, it's too small and the selection is limited.  The Pineville location is just too much to get in and out of there and everything is picked over.  This location is somewhat convenient for me though, and it is an easy, almost traffic free drive to get there.  The people are also very friendly.

attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 3, 'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': False, 'valet': False}, 'BikeParking': True}
name: Peppermint Forest Christmas Shop
text: I finally visited this place after driving by it for years. You'll notice that the signs also say "Oasis Pools." From October through December, it is Peppermint Forest and from January to October, it is Oasis Pools and they sell pools, spas, and outdoor living accessories. If you have been in Charlotte for a while and remember Anna Koiman who was on the local Fox News when Fox was channel 18, it is her parents that own the businesses. I have been to a lot of Christmas stores in other cities but those typically sell a lot more stuff than Peppermint Forest but of cheaper quality. Peppermint Forest is relatively small compared to those but they carry higher quality products that are more expensive. Some of their artificial trees are $600-800 each to give you an idea but damn they look nice. They also sell unique collectibles including handmade wooden nativity scenes from Italy. They recently even had the member of the family who makes them as a special guest.We bought a very nice tree topper which again was slightly expensive but sturdy. I also went today (after Christmas) and everything was 50 per cent off, including storage for artificial trees. I bought one for $15 after the discount and it is sturdy. This place is also very pretty when it is Peppermint Forest. When you walk in, you feel like you are in a Christmas forest with all of the trees and other decorations. The employees are friendly but since they are mostly seasonal, they may need to ask one of the owners for assistance and the owners are nice. The bottom line: Don't go here if you are looking for discount store prices or quality. However, if you're willing and able to spend a few extra bucks for something of higher quality, this is the place. And after Christmas, everything is 50% off except for a few specialty items.

attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'BikeParking': True}
name: Walmart Neighborhood Market
text: On my first trip to this store, I stopped by to get beer and bananas. I thought it was going to be very busy on the first day but it was not. The store is the size of a small Harris Teeter or Bi-lo, and carries the same essential products. In addition to food, they sell cleaning supplies, pet supplies, and medicine (the store has a pharmacy like most stores this size). They do not sell TVs, toys, clothes, etc. Like all Walmart owned entities, they accept the chip payment cards which is a huge plus. They are also open 24/7 which makes it the only store on the east end of Fort Mill that is.The store seems a little dismal on the inside because of the grey used in it despite the bright green used on the outside of the store. Some things seem to be out of place. Prepared, packaged chicken is not near the fresh chicken and it took me a while to find it. The selection is limited. For example, they carry Stouffer's frozen entrees. Despite the store being the same size as the other grocery stores in the area, they only carry a few options of those. I bought a half gallon of store-brand organic milk which was only slightly cheaper than Bi-lo or HT. I also bought a dozen store-brand cage free eggs that were about a dollar cheaper than the name brands. I checked the eggs and ensured that none were broke. When I took one out to prepare, it was broken on the bottom. It was not a fresh break; it had been broken long before. I removed the few eggs from the tat side and cooked the rest. They did not taste that good.The parking lot is small, easy, and efficient. It can be accessed from 160 or N. Doby's Bridge Rd. The building is a huge aesthetic improvement over the previous mostly vacant building that was demolished. This Neighborhood Walmart is a nice addition to Fort Mill.

attributes: {'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': True, 'valet': False}, 'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 3, 'BikeParking': True, 'ByAppointmentOnly': False, 'WheelchairAccessible': True}
name: Verizon
text: I rarely go into a cell phone store, but my phone stopped working.  I went to this location and the girl working got me in quickly.  Within a few minutes a new phone was on the way to me and I received it the next day since I have the warranty on the phone.  It was great customer service and was not only painless but also somewhat pleasant since the girl working was so nice.

attributes: {'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': True, 'valet': False}, 'Caters': True, 'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 2, 'BikeParking': True, 'RestaurantTakeOut': False, 'ByAppointmentOnly': False, 'WheelchairAccessible': True}
name: Total Wine & More
text: Total Wine and More is like a big grocery store for wine and beer. They have a great variety of wine and also craft beer.  You can find almost anything in here.  If you're a beer snob, check inside the beer fridge for beer from local breweries that bottle and can their beer. You can also get kegs of local beer or mass produced cheap beer.  They also fill growlers for reasonable prices.  They even have some food offerings, including Boar's Head cheeses (would like to see more cheese to go with the wines). The staff is very knowledgeable.

attributes: {'DogsAllowed': True, 'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': True, 'valet': False}, 'WiFi': 'free', 'OutdoorSeating': True, 'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': False, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 2, 'BikeParking': True, 'WheelchairAccessible': True}
name: Charlotte Premium Outlets
text: It's an outlet mall, but wow is it poorly designed.  An outdoor floor plan and parking lot both with little shade in heart of the Carolinas where it's in the 90s for almost half of the year?  The parking is very limited; there just are not enough spaces (2000 for 100 stores?).  Wait until the holidays because this is going to be mess.  There are only two Restaurant in the "food court" now open. That does not count the Chk-fil-a selling $5 tiny chicken sandwiches and 12 ounce Cokes for $2 when 20 ounces of the latter can be found cheaper in the machine or food court Restaurant.  You are a table with one employee; you have no overhead so you are ripping people off.Some of the stores have real outlet deals; others not.  I found a pair of jeans in my size (36x36) which is very difficult to find at Eddie Bauer for $23.  That was a pretty good deal.  Many of the other stores seem to be selling stuff at regular retail prices.  I will say some of the Labor Day sales were good; others not so much - $25 off of $250 at Tommy Hilfiger?  Pass.It's nice to have in the area but I don;t think I will return regularly.

attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 2, 'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': True, 'valet': False}, 'BikeParking': False}
name: Sears Roebuck and
text: I must say that Sears has impressed me over the last couple of weeks.  I ordered an electric mower online to pick up in store and the process was so easy, plus I got 4% cash back for going through http://www.ebates.com/rf.do?referrerid=D%2BzVWKmRzUJI8C90ZWeLZA%3D%3D  They emailed me to confirm the order was ready in minutes.  I printed the email, borught it to the store, scanned the bar code at the kiosk, and the employee brought the mower out within 2 minutes.  If they don't bring your order out in 5 minutes, they will give you a $5 off coupon.  The employee also brought it to my car and put it in my trunk.A few days later, I saw that the price had dropped by $16.  Sears has a 14 day price match guarantee, including their own stores, so I filled out their quick online form.  The next day I received an email stating they were refunding my credit card for $16!  Though this store carries more and is a little more organized than the Rock Hill store, I also had a good experience there yesterday, so a review for them is soon to come.

attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 2, 'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': True, 'valet': False}, 'BikeParking': True}
name: Sam's Club
text: Best deal you will find on tires anywhere.  Be careful with the groceries though - some are way more than what you would pay at a grocery store.  Store brand medications are also the cheapest you'll find anywhere.  The best thing is that while waiting for your tires to be installed, you can walk around eating samples, sit in rocking or anti-gravity chairs, or grab a cheap slice of pizza or bottle of water (67 cents) from the cafe.  You can also watch TV, mess around with the computers, or bring your memory card and get photos for 8 cents each.  Basically, it's worth the $40 membership for tires - and they include free lifetime rotation too.

attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 2, 'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': True, 'valet': False}, 'BikeParking': True, 'WheelchairAccessible': True}
name: IKEA
text: IKEA is alright but not all it's cracked up to be.  While I love the ideas for space saving, most of the furniture isn't Swedish.  Much of it is actually the same cheap "Made in China" stuff that Walmart sells.  Most of it did not look very durable.  People rave about the restaurant in there, but iceberg salad and spinach crepes that have been sitting in a warmer for who knows how long aren't even as good as hopsital food is these days.  The whole way to shop is a pain too.  See what you want and write it down while wandering this monstrosity?  If they can be so efficient with designs of rooms, why can't they make they building more efficient?  It really is ironic when you think about it.  I'd go to Ikea again, but I'm not in a rush to do so.

attributes: {'RestaurantPriceRange2': 2, 'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': True, 'valet': False}, 'BikeParking': True, 'WheelchairAccessible': True}
name: Northlake Mall
text: Whoever built a mall at the corner of 77 and WT Harris Blvd has probably since been fired.  It deserves only two stars, but one extra is being awarded because it is by far the least crowded big mall in or near Charlotte.  It was slow before The Great Recession, and is still slow.  No longer can the recession be blamed for lack of business because if I go to Carolina Place, South park, or Concord Mills, I can't find a parking spot on the weekend.  This mall isn't even busy at Christmas time!  I think they may have been banking on 485 opening to the mall - which it did 3 years ago, but that hasn't helped business either.It has your typical stores, most of which it shares with Carolina Place, and an AMC Theater which is only accessible from outside the mall (very odd for a mall theatre).  The food court is typical as is the mandatory Starbucks.  I do like that the main restrooms near the food court have waterless urinals - those things are awesome.There also some decent Restaurant like Bravo's but I generally don't go to a mall to go to restaurant.  The anchor stores are oddly placed - like Dillard's at the far end of the mall.  Most Dillard's are slow, so they don't need anything to hinder their business (hint - if you can't find a place to park at a mall and it has a Dillard's, there will usually be places to park).  The mall also a cool "man zone" type place.  They have a couple of TVs with sports so you can watch tv while the significant other shops.  Northlake isn't too bad for being a mall, but it's average at best.

attributes: {'Alcohol': 'beer_and_wine', 'HasTV': True, 'NoiseLevel': 'average', 'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'Music': {'dj': False, 'background_music': False, 'no_music': False, 'karaoke': False, 'live': False, 'video': False, 'jukebox': False}, 'Ambience': {'romantic': False, 'intimate': False, 'classy': False, 'hipster': False, 'divey': False, 'touristy': False, 'trendy': True, 'upscale': False, 'casual': True}, 'RestaurantGoodForGroups': True, 'Caters': False, 'WiFi': 'free', 'RestaurantReservations': False, 'BikeParking': True, 'Smoking': 'outdoor', 'HappyHour': False, 'WheelchairAccessible': True, 'DogsAllowed': True, 'OutdoorSeating': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 2, 'RestaurantTakeOut': False, 'BestNights': {'monday': False, 'tuesday': False, 'friday': True, 'wednesday': False, 'thursday': True, 'sunday': False, 'saturday': True}, 'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': True, 'valet': False}, 'CoatCheck': False, 'GoodForDancing': False}
name: Vin Master
text: Love this little hidden gem of a wine shop.  I've been to tastings with Vin Master before but for whatever reason I had never actually been to the store to check it out before this weekend.Upon entering you will see a wide array of wines stored along the walls and across tables.  They are labled in categories that I prefer like, spicey, fruity, etc.  That's how I decide on wines.  The staff here is super easy going and will make you feel right at home in a moment's notice.Here's another great thing I like, they tend to cater to exceptionally value minded wine drinkers like me.  I don't want to continually buy $30+ bottles of wine.  That's ok now and again but give me a $14 bottle and I'll be just fine.  They have a large selection right along that price point.  I'm sure you will find something you like.The only thing keeping me from making this a 5 star review is I really wish there were some food offerings to go along with the glasses of wine you can purchase.  Oh well, I'll just eat next door at Big Ben's and then come over.

attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 3, 'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': True, 'valet': False}, 'BikeParking': True, 'WheelchairAccessible': True}
name: Charlotte Running Co.
text: After purchasing an awesome Groupon for $25 off some new shoes I was very excited to get into some tires!  I had probably 400 miles on my old shoes and was in need.  I know how dedicated running stores work and my experience has been that they will promote their preferences sometimes in lieu of what you may want.  That being said I've learned to just force them to find a shoe model from the brand I prefer.  The staff was slammed so I'm giving them a reprieve but I expected a bit more friendliness.  Honestly, they need a woman's touch in customer service.  Sorry, I'm a male but I can recognize too much testosterone when I see it.  I felt like I was bothering them instead of being a profit center.I'll probably come back based on the selection I saw, I was very impressed and I like the treadmill analysis that they provide.  That was helpful.NOTE:  Right now there is a check in offer that will score you a free pair of socks with a shoe purchase!

attributes: {'Alcohol': 'beer_and_wine', 'Caters': False, 'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 2, 'BikeParking': True, 'RestaurantDelivery': False, 'RestaurantTakeOut': False, 'WheelchairAccessible': True, 'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': True, 'validated': False, 'lot': False, 'valet': False}}
name: Carolina Beer Temple
text: Seriously, if you live in the area and you have a disposition for good beer, you MUST try this place out.  No food there, but there are food choices around.  Mindful of that, just come in, grab a pint and then do a little craft beer shopping to your hearts content.  I made my first stop in last week and was pretty impressed by the rareity of some of the beers and the bountiful selection of some of the more decent ones.  The service was more than happy to help pick out something to try and the atmosphere in general was very relaxed and nothing like say, a Total Wine kind of experience.  They have bar seating if you like as well as some high top tables and also some lounge chairs to help kick back and take it all in.  This place is nice.

attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 3, 'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': True, 'valet': False}, 'BikeParking': True, 'WheelchairAccessible': True}
name: Bruce Julian Clothier
text: A real mens clothier.  That's the bottom line with this place.  The price point can probably turn most away but I look at it a bit differently.  I figure that you can either go to Nordstrom, etc. and spend nearly the same amount and get not even close the amount of personal service.These people working here really know how to treat you.  Wine while you shop, recommendations on suitable attire and descriptions about the designers even.  I also love the fact that you can get a cool funky design or if you are leaning to something more conservative, they have that too.  Once you've fell in love with that special jacket, shirt, or pants they will even alter the clothes to give you that perfect fit right in the store.  No fussing around taking it somewhere else.  I suspect these people go to great lenghts to take care of all their customers.Bottom line, if you want personal service and to feel like a million bucks, go here.

attributes: {'DogsAllowed': True, 'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': True, 'validated': False, 'lot': True, 'valet': False}, 'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 2, 'BikeParking': True, 'ByAppointmentOnly': False, 'WheelchairAccessible': True}
categories: ["Women's Clothing", 'Flowers & Gifts', 'Fashion', 'Arts & Crafts', 'Shopping', 'Event Planning & Services', 'Jewelry', 'Cards & Stationery']
name: The Boulevard at South End
text: I love shopping local and this place is the epitemy of that.  Located on South Tryon it's not a far venture from uptown or Southend.  The interior is chock full of unique items that will complete your desire for unique home furnishings, clothing and accessories.I popped in there and once past the furnishing I noticed the clothing and while the majority is geared towards women there is a little section for us guys.  I picked up a cool wallet, watch and a gift for my son.  Everything is just so unique and that's important to me because I don't want to see something I'm wearing on someone else if I can help it.The service here is fantastic and probably some of the most pleasant smiles you'll find in Charlotte.

attributes: {'DogsAllowed': False, 'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': True, 'validated': False, 'lot': True, 'valet': False}, 'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 3, 'GoodForKids': False, 'ByAppointmentOnly': False, 'WheelchairAccessible': True}
name: Lark & Key Gallery and Boutique
text: As my girlfriend is a pottery-holic I had to stop in here to check out what they had to offer in the way of a Christmas gift.  I'm glad I did.  They have some really beautiful stuff here and most of it, if not all of it, are local artists.  The young lady working there while I was there was very patient in explaining the artists works and helping me find a perfect gift.  As a solid bonus, her husband is an artist that has multiple paintings on the walls and she threw in a free reprint of one of his paintings for me.  That was really cool and I hope to frame it soon.Support local and shop here!

attributes: {'DogsAllowed': True, 'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': True, 'valet': False}, 'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 2, 'BusinessAcceptsBitcoin': False, 'BikeParking': True, 'WheelchairAccessible': True}
name: Off Broadway Shoes
text: After being turned onto this place by my girlfriend I'll admit I'm a fan.  They won't have the latest styles but they have plenty of great late model shoes to browse through.  I probably wouldn't suggest this place for a real sport shoe, like running or whatever your sport is but the dress shoe selection and casual shoes here are great.Always clean and friendly service and not to mention a rewards program will keep you coming back for sure.

attributes: {'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': True, 'valet': False}, 'Caters': False, 'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 2, 'BikeParking': True, 'RestaurantTakeOut': False}
name: Crafty Beer Guys
text: Simply put, I dig this place.  It's an old home in the old section of Huntersville that has been converted to provide a few taps, wine and craft beer bottles.The place has separate rooms for people to sit and enjoy their drinks as well as a couch in front of a fireplace with an original NES hooked up to a TV above it.   That is a cool plus!  If the weather was better we would have loved to hang out on the front porch too.  Just a cool atmosphere all around.Not much room in the bar area for seating and the craft beer selection, while great, isn't stocked full of really rare beers but still full of great ones all the same.Highly recommended.

attributes: {'DogsAllowed': True, 'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': True, 'valet': False}, 'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 2, 'BikeParking': True, 'ByAppointmentOnly': False, 'WheelchairAccessible': True}
categories: ['Bookstores', 'Flowers & Gifts', 'Cards & Stationery', 'Shopping', 'Event Planning & Services', 'Books', 'Mags', 'Music & Video', 'Gift Shops', 'Arts & Crafts', 'Jewelry']
name: Paper Skyscraper
text: What's not to say here about Paper Skyscraper.  It's a great place to spend time if you want to waste some time and can't think of anything to do.  I promise you, you could spend a solid hour in here just browsing all the cool quirky items.  Their stock really runs the gambit from greeting cards (that are hilarious by the way) to adult toys and games.  There is also a great selection of historical books on Dilworth and the Charlotte area for those that want to know more about the area they live in.  I know that I will be back to get that hard to find birthday gift for that someone that really has everything already.  I can guarantee you that you will find something they absolutely don't already have here!

attributes: {'Alcohol': 'beer_and_wine', 'Caters': True, 'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 2, 'BusinessAcceptsBitcoin': False, 'BikeParking': True, 'RestaurantDelivery': True, 'RestaurantTakeOut': True, 'WheelchairAccessible': True, 'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': True, 'valet': False}}
name: Healthy Home Market - Plaza
text: New location, same great assortment of healthy food and goods.  Just popped in the other day and it still looks like they are unloading into the new space.  I was glad to see the same smiling faces and the same products from the old store.While some of the things are overpriced IMO, the selection can't be beat for those looking for the upper crust relative to organic and health foods.  The only drawback and the reason for the 3-star review is the sheer amount of vendor tables setup peddeling samples, etc.  It was just too much given the smaller space they now have.  One or two would have been alright, but it felt like there were people at every turn.  Maybe it's just during this opening time frame, I sure hope so.

attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 2, 'BusinessParking': {'garage': True, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': False, 'valet': False}, 'BikeParking': False}
name: Houdini's Magic Shop
text: Presto! Voila! Houdini's was a nice little find for some unique souvenirs for my son. There's a ton of magic tricks, booklets and books to choose from cheap to the more expensive. It was easy to put together a magic primer batch of a few cheesy tricks. And the tricks have little Skill Levels on them, so you know what you're getting into!The three guys working the counter here were goofy and having fun, which makes the store a relaxed visit. They were hands off, mostly, but quick to help when asked a question and friendly during checkout. Now, I wonder if I'll have a li'l Houdini on my hands...I hope so!

attributes: {'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': False, 'valet': False}, 'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 2, 'BikeParking': True, 'GoodForKids': False, 'ByAppointmentOnly': False}
name: Hatch Art House
text: Hatch Art House has carefully chosen art pieces all in one shop. I'm really surprised at the lack of Yelp reviews (huge gap between 2014 to 2017), perhaps greater awareness among Madison Yelpers is needed? It's a great place for local art buying and is attached to Hazel General Store, a great space for makers' products. I think my only recommendation is to merge the two adjoining stores under one name- because each portion just adds to the overall impact of one art and makers' space.

attributes: {'DogsAllowed': True, 'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': True, 'validated': False, 'lot': True, 'valet': False}, 'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 2, 'BikeParking': True, 'ByAppointmentOnly': False, 'WheelchairAccessible': True}
categories: ['Home & Service', 'Furniture Stores', 'Fashion', 'Used', 'Vintage & Consignment', 'Flowers & Gifts', 'Gift Shops', 'Home & Garden', 'Shopping', 'Antiques', 'Home Decor']
name: Pieces Unimagined
text: Very cool vintage shop. Good mix of furniture, typewriters, electric and industrial antiques, records, as well as some new makers pieces, like letters sawed out of old books. Things seemed fairly priced, and there was an employee on duty, fixing things, not hounding people. Although I kinda wish he had hounded the older lady who thought it was okay to sit on a couch and have a loud personal speaker phone call for 30 minutes (not related to buying a piece, or anything). For sure worth a stop!

attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 2, 'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': False, 'valet': False}, 'BikeParking': True, 'WheelchairAccessible': True}
categories: ['Flowers & Gifts', 'Home Decor', 'Shopping', 'Home & Garden', 'Art Supplies', 'Event Planning & Services', 'Cards & Stationery', 'Arts & Crafts']
name: Hazel General Store
text: I'm really surprised to see so few Yelp reviews for Hatch and Hazel. Hazel General Store is a cool place on Willy Street for carefully chosen makers' items, many locally made. Screen printed t-shirts, handmade soaps, greeting cards, they're all here. I think my only recommendation is to merge the two adjoining stores under one name- because each portion just adds to the overall impact of one art and makers' space.

attributes: {'DogsAllowed': False, 'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': True, 'validated': False, 'lot': False, 'valet': False}, 'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 1, 'BikeParking': True, 'ByAppointmentOnly': False, 'WheelchairAccessible': True}
name: Tropic Jewel
text: When you're friends with someone who can make jewelry, you not only act as her enabler, but you exploit her for all the free handmade jewelry you can.  Thus it was, on a trip to Madison, that I cleverly took my jewelin' pal into Tropic Jewel for a quick supply run, while secretly planning to turn her into my own personal one-woman sweatshop.First I must tell you that Tropic Jewel is flippin' hot in summertime.  It's on the second story of this weird strip mall, so you not only have to haul yourself up a flight of stairs, but once you get up there, there's no A/C waiting for you.  Pause and catch your breath before heading in, because it gets stuffy in there when it's crowded.If you have any interest in jewelry-making at all, though, is this ever the place for you.  Shelves and shelves of bead trays, sorted by color, contain every kind of bead you could imagine and then some.  One whole table is devoted to pearls, natural and dyed.  In addition to smaller beads, they have large semi-precious stone pendants and even some metal pendants.  There's also a good selection of findings, tools, and kits.  I especially liked the beginners' kits, which had everything you needed to make, say, a pair of chandelier earrings or a bracelet.  Lots of times those beginners' kits are pretty lame, but these projects were actually cool things that you'd want to wear - or give as gifts.We picked out some nice coin pearls, glass beads, and other beads for me, and with my friend's help, I ended up getting three pairs of earrings for less than what one pair would have cost in a department store.  But even if you're not a jewelry expert, the staff is helpful and will answer your questions, and I believe they even hold classes there to teach beginners how to use their new purchases.If you can take the heat (it's not called Tropic Jewel for nothing), this is a nice place to browse, plan projects, or pick up a piece of finished jewelry for yourself or someone else.  It was almost enough to make me want to take up beading myself - like I need another time-sucking hobby in my life.

attributes: {'GoodForMeal': {'dessert': False, 'latenight': False, 'lunch': False, 'dinner': False, 'breakfast': False, 'brunch': False}, 'DogsAllowed': False, 'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': True, 'valet': False}, 'RestaurantGoodForGroups': True, 'NoiseLevel': 'average', 'WiFi': 'free', 'RestaurantAttire': 'casual', 'RestaurantReservations': False, 'OutdoorSeating': False, 'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': False, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 2, 'BikeParking': True, 'RestaurantDelivery': False, 'RestaurantTakeOut': True, 'GoodForKids': True, 'WheelchairAccessible': True}
name: Las Vegas South Premium Outlets
text: Looking for bargains in Vegas?  Don't go to the Strip, with its skeevy souvenir stores and pricey casino malls.  Instead, head over to the Las Vegas Outlet Mall, where you can actually get something for your money besides the thrill of plunking it into a one-armed bandit.This outlet mall is huge, and it just goes on and on...and on.  And on.  It's so big that there are two food courts, and one of them is located next to a carousel.  Yes, there is a somewhat random feel to the layout and selection of stores, but it's such a diverse mix that there will be something for everyone in your group to browse through - though you might have some trouble meeting up again later.Some of my favorite stores include the Fossil outlet, which has tables of $20 and $30 watches (but make sure they check the battery before you leave); Charlotte Russe, which has a fun mix of funky and bohemian women's clothes, and a giant clearance rack in the back (I got a super-cute skirt there for $8 that I wear all the time); Vans, which has styles you won't see in regular stores and a big sale section; and Levi's, where you can get irregulars for half the price of normal Levi's.Other notable stores include Liz Claiborne, Jones New York, Nike, Reebok, and Tommy Hilfiger.  Shoe lovers will find Adidas, Bass, Skechers, and Naturalizers, among others.  There are home furnishings stores (Mikasa, Black & Decker), leather stores (Wilson, and, soon, Coach), and gourmet foods (Harry & David, Rocky Mountain Chocolate Factory).  As with any "outlet" mall, there are some stores that seem suspiciously non-outlet, and some weird stores that are just oddball (like the rocks 'n' geodes shop).  Plan to spend at least an afternoon here, particularly if you're hiding out from the intense Vegas heat.  You may spend more than you planned - I always do - but unlike at the casinos, at least you'll have something to show for it when you head back home.

attributes: {'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': False, 'valet': False}, 'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 4, 'BikeParking': False, 'GoodForKids': False, 'ByAppointmentOnly': False}
name: The Wynn Collection
text: Okay, I know what you're thinking: Vegas is to fine art as gritty, greasy oil is to pure, clean glacial water.  But no!  There is art to be found in the City of Sin... you just have to know where to look.  For example, the Wynn Casino.Steve Wynn, if you didn't know, is not only mind-bogglingly rich but also a patron of the arts, and a major art collector.  Some of the paintings he has are things you'd never expect to see outside a museum.  The Wynn Collection came to the Nevada Museum of Art (in Reno) last year, so I saw it then, and was impressed.  When the Wynn casino opened, the collection initially had its own gallery, nestled off the main floor near the shops, which Nevada residents could get into for $3, making it one of the few genuine bargains in Vegas.But since money is, after all, the prime consideration, the gallery was closed earlier this year due to poor ticket sales, and the space will be converted into retail space for more of the couture brands that already grace the Wynn's shopping mall.  Fortunately, the art itself didn't go away, and the pieces have been redistributed around the casino, with the showpiece - Picasso's "Le Reve" - displayed in the main lobby.I haven't seen the collection since it was taken out of the gallery, but it's an impressive selection of pieces by Warhol, Singer, van Gogh, Manet, Gaugin, and Jan Brueghel the Younger, among others.  If you have the patience and stamina for a casino-wide scavenger hunt, this is likely the best free show you'll see in Vegas.

categories: ['Event Planning & Services', 'Wholesale Stores', 'Specialty Food', 'Grocery', 'Food', 'Food Delivery Services', 'Caterers', 'Shopping']
name: Willy Street Grocery Co-Op - East
text: After spending a day in Madison, I started making a mental pros/cons list about why boyfriend should apply to UW Madison for law school.  This is one of those pros.  This store has so many goodies some of  which are reasonably priced, others of which are not.  Sweet and Sara vegan marshmallows were more expensive than at Whole Foods in Chicago, but other things like the eggs were cheaper than at the co-op I usually go to.  They carry Upton's seitan which is a fave of mine, and a ton of great quality produce.  If I lived here, I'd become a member, b/c quite frankly, you really have to to shop here.  10% upcharge for non members.  Harrumpf.

attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 2, 'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': True, 'validated': False, 'lot': False, 'valet': False}, 'BikeParking': True, 'WheelchairAccessible': True}
name: Capital City Comics
text: This small, no-frills shop is a little like the Android's Dungeon, only the owner isn't an obese mega-nerd.  They have some of the newer selections, as well as some magazines, zines, graphic novels, and a few art books.  I was able to get my paws on the new Daniel Clowes book I've been waiting on.  They also have a nice selection of back issues, but most of them are not organized by price, or visibly priced, and the owner has to look each of them up individually, which can be a pain if your boyfriend loves buying piles of comics.

attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 2, 'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': False, 'valet': False}}
name: Rainbow Bookstore Cooperative
text: Need a cola flavored lollipop of Lenin's face?  If so, this is the store for you.  They also sell other things here, such as books.  That primitive form of TV we all used to know and love.  This is a goldmine of leftist reading materials and they have everything from vegan cookbooks, to labor history books (even ones by my fellow Pilsen resident Kari Lydersen!) , to kids books about the food chain.  They also have artsy books, zines, and a fairly extensive sale section.  Boyfriend even managed to find a replacement for a stolen kaffiyeh here.  The guy running the shop is great.  The sale section was still a little rich for my blood.  Why are all the good ones still $15?  Nuts.  Oh well, this is what happens when you usually shop thrift.  At least you can suck on Lenin's face while pouting over it.

attributes: {'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': False, 'valet': False}, 'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 2, 'BikeParking': True, 'GoodForKids': False, 'WheelchairAccessible': False}
name: Ear Wax Records
text: If you're not careful, you might walk out of here with a bejewelled skull and no money.  Or maybe the broken shards of a Slayer signed guitar.  What about a violin with pointy screws sticking out of it?  I almost bought some metal baby gear, but stopped the money hemorrhage for once.  Boyfriend picked some CDs from the discount box.  If I hadn't been feeling cheap, I would have pillaged the fairly extensive psychobilly section, but that will be a treat for another trip.  Need metal?  Get Ear Wax.

attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 3, 'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': True, 'validated': False, 'lot': False, 'valet': False}, 'BikeParking': True, 'WheelchairAccessible': True}
name: Wild Child
text: Fun fact: I have a tradition of buying my almost two year old a book from each city I visit, whether it's for work or fun. So when I was heading to Barriques to meet Corey D for a coffee and walked past Wild Child I had to divert myself for a few minutes to step into this cool little kids shop and see if I could find something to bring home.There is a decent selection of clothing in a wide variety of sizes. I saw some of my favorite brands in the store as well as a neat selection of locally made stuff. The toy selection was a bit smaller than the clothing, but just as carefully curated and I did indeed find quite a few options for a book to buy Little Man E. If I lived in the area (or had more room in my luggage) I would have definitely bought something from their music area as they had fun drums and other instruments that were sized for tiny hands and reasonably priced. The man working in the store was super helpful and very pleasant and I could see stopping in here regularly if I lived in the area.

attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 2, 'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': True, 'valet': False}, 'BikeParking': True, 'WheelchairAccessible': True}
name: American Apparel
text: I don't normally go into American Apparel. Mostly because I like vintage and things that are skintight don't look good on me. But, I was dressing up as a mermaid and found myself in need of a top to wear under my shells so I didn't expose too much skin. Of course, American Apparel had all the selection of shiny, skintight (and skin colored) tops I needed. While I feel like I way over-paid for what I got, at least I got what I needed.

attributes: {'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': False, 'valet': False}, 'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 3, 'GoodForKids': True, 'ByAppointmentOnly': False, 'WheelchairAccessible': True}
name: Fanny Garver Gallery
text: Thank you, thank you, thank you!!I wandered in after a loooonnnngggg day of meetings- I was meandering  around the hotel area, trying to clear my head.  I had never stepped into this particular gallery, but, the windows looked enticing. They were in the midst of a trunk jewelry show, the goods were awesome!  I finished my Christmas shopping here!  I picked up an unusual pair of chestnut brown Pineconeish shaped earrings for my sister in law, and a matching necklace with strands of woven metal in chestnut, bronze, and a deep green.  Totally unusual and beautiful.  I want to keep it for myself, but alas, must pass it along. I also picked up a hand crafted wooden box with Maple and Cherry wood, fantastic burled wood top.  These purchases completed my Christmas shopping, and are guaranteed to be hits.  My colleague picked up some gifts also.  I am heading back into town next week.  I will be stopping to pick up another item for a friend.  Love it!!

attributes: {'Open24Hours': False, 'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': False, 'valet': False}, 'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 2, 'BikeParking': True, 'WheelchairAccessible': True}
name: Madison Museum of Contemporary Art Store
text: Hidden gem.  Who would-a-thought?Great glass pieces.  I tiptoed around vases, ornaments, as well as a couple Chihuly pieces.  Yes, I admit, i did experience visions of grandeur as I dreamed of purchasing my own Chihuly-and actually, for 2 seconds, considered plunking my AMEX down for one. As I inched closer, eyeing the colors in the glass, I slightly slipped on the wet concrete floor- my high heeled boots failing once again in the traction arena (Seriously, life is ABOUT looking HOT, NOT COMFORT OR SAFETY- Why wear snow boots in 4 inches of snow and ice when you have fantastic knee high leather boots with 3 inch heels that also keep your footsies dry?). At this point in time, I had ANXIETY ATTACK evoking visions of having to PURCHASE the ENTIRE WALL OF GLASS due to breakage...AND I quietly started to hyperventilate. Thank GOD some air got into my oxygen starved brain and reality returned. I scampered away from the breakable objects- my bank account sent me a heartfelt CONGRATULATIONS the next day.I found myself across the store, glanced guiltily around to make sure no one saw my moments of weakness, panic,  utter grace, and started browsing through the purses.  Cause ya all know I can always use another purse! They had some unique purses too!  Handmade, multiple fabric pieces.  Luckily, none were approaching suitcase size, which as you may also know, is about the only size I can function with.  (WELL, what do you expect, with sunglasses as big as mine,2 cell phones, my wallet, essentials, and 1/2 of the prescription narcotic stock found in CVS,  really, a purse that big is NON NEGOTIABLE).I also managed to resist the jewelery.  They had some shiny silver pieces with great texture. Feeling like a bird attracted to shiny objects, I hovered over the case, drooled for a bit -then raced to look at the children's books. Somehow, I managed to make it out of the store without brandishing my AMEX, but... I am not making any promises about future visits...

attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 1, 'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': True, 'valet': False}, 'BikeParking': True, 'WheelchairAccessible': True}
name: Half Price Books
text: I can never get enough to read.  It does not have to be high quality literature, trashy vampire novels read well too!  When I travel, I burn through a book about every 2 days, I really don't watch TV (except for Rock of Love), and refuse to do so in a hotel room.  Since sitting at a hotel bar is in my opinion: 1. Stupid 2. A waste of time- I don't drink by myself and don't pick up strangers 3. Somewhat dangerous- business men on the prowl at hotels can be really scary...So obviously I need something to occupy my time.  I found half price books in Madison on one of my first trips there this year.  I love it.  I have been able to purchase books that I want to read for- literally- half price.Caveat-- Make sure the book you are buying is in decent shape.  I don't think they screen them that well.  Last time, I was happy to pick up a paperback by an author I enjoy, and did not realize that the binding was broken.  It should have been about 25 cents, not the 3.50 I paid for it.  But- buyer beware, I learned my lesson, and will check more closely next time!

attributes: {'DogsAllowed': True, 'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': True, 'valet': False}, 'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 2, 'BikeParking': False, 'GoodForKids': False, 'ByAppointmentOnly': True, 'WheelchairAccessible': True}
name: La Bella Vita
text: I found La Bella Vita online because they cary a large selection of jewelry from our favorite Montreal jeweler, Christophe Poly. His work is *stunning*, with layered geometric shapes cast in silver and copper, melded with colorful stones. We first found his rings, necklaces, and bracelets while on vacation in Quebec. Wifey would have bought every single ring she found if I let her. She gets all kinds of compliments on the one ring she did get.Now we're home from vacation and I'm going to surprise her with an anniversary gift from Christophe Poly's collection. Unfortunately, because he works mostly with small galleries and independent resellers, and each piece is unique, his work is hard to find online. Alissa from La Bella Vita helped me select a gorgeous necklace and is shipping it right away so it will get here in time. She was super helpful and friendly on the phone. I can't wait to see the necklace in person. Shhhh... don't tell wifey!

categories: ['Music & DVDs', 'Guitar Stores', 'Books', 'Mags', 'Music & Video', 'Local Services', 'Musical Instrument Services', 'Shopping', 'Musical Instruments & Teachers', 'Specialty Schools', 'Education']
name: Madison Music
text: When I first moved to Madison, I made a list of all the guitar shops and then spent at least an hour in each one. As a player, I know that sooner or later, I would need to buy strings,  need adjustments made to my instruments, maybe even buy a new one. It's very hard to find 'The One" store in any town but you need to know what's out there.I was really impressed with MMC. I spent at least an hour playing several different gorgeous acoustic guitars that I could never afford. I was "looking" at several parlor-size guitars to perhaps replace my Baby Taylor (for travel). I took them through their paces and worked them over pretty well. The guy I spoke with was knowledgeable, helpful but never in my face. After hearing me play, he even  recommended a local player that I might be interested in hearing.They don't do repairs and suggested two other shops that I had already been to for the adjustments I would need. I bought strings and a couple of acoustic guitar humidifiers. I wouldn't call them snobby, they're simply serious about quality acoustic guitars. Great shop!

attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 2, 'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': True, 'valet': False}}
name: Williamson Bicycle Works
text: I was in a bit of a pickle. I needed a bike that had been boxed up and shipped cross-country, re-assembled ... and I needed it done on a Sunday and ready for my first Madison Monday morning commute to my new job. I called around to a few bike shops. "Drop it off, we might have it ready on Wednesday", says one shop. "Today? I need it to get to work?".   "I suggest you call around you might find some mechanic who has time." Williamson BW said, "Sure, we can put it together, check it out and probably get it to you by 5 PM". We dropped it of at the bustling service station. Tono, the guy I talked to on the phone was agreeable, reassuring and, as promised, called at 4:30. What I haven't told you yet was that this was an old Schwinn 3 speed that had been in a box for at least a year. "It took a lot of oil to get things moving, I had to replace one cable and a tire (an obscure-sized vintage Schwinn part that they actually carried!)", he said as he handed me back a cleaned up, functioning bike.Before I left, I spent a few minutes looking at other city bikes. The salesman (Jon) was friendly and helpful. He explained the differences between the models, listened to my questions and zeroed in on a sweet, new, lightweight and inexpensive single speed with just the frame geometry I was looking for. Not pushy, just helpful. Tono (the mechanic), you are The Man! Thank you. I just found my new bike shop.

name: Sacred Feather
text: I never was much of a hat wearer but I've purchased two hats here in one year. Having had too much sun exposure in my youth, I've needed more sun protection to ward off the Consequences. During a short visit last summer I needed head covering right away and found the perfect 'Gilligan" fishing hat that saved the day, Recently, as the weather cooled and my straw 'plantation' hats would no longer suffice. My son picked out a nice felt Indy Jones number and it's working out just fine.The selection, the price range, the service.All Great!

attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 3, 'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': True, 'validated': False, 'lot': False, 'valet': False}, 'BikeParking': True, 'WheelchairAccessible': True}
name: Wild Child
text: Fun little shop!  Love that they carry Zutano, Jefferies Socks, Haba, Robeez, etc. The guy behind the counter was very welcoming and nice.  Well laid out for a small shop, filled with great stuff, but not overwhelmingly packed - plenty of room to move around and browse.  A great spot to find age appropriate, fun and whimsical clothing items.  Wonderful place to find unique gifts.My one complaint is their prices - a bit too high! Though, I realize they must have a smaller inventory, etc. which will be reflected in prices... Overall, great little shop and I look forward to visiting again when we're back in Madison.

attributes: {'BusinessParking': {'garage': True, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': False, 'valet': False}, 'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantPriceRange2': 2, 'BikeParking': False, 'ByAppointmentOnly': False, 'WheelchairAccessible': True}
name: Basin White
text: Clean, well designed, easy to navigate.  Loved this place.  Picked up a few bath bombs, scents are fantastic and found a table of $10 "Mystery Bags" in the back... GET ONE, mine was loaded with six of their gorgeous bars of soap!  $40.00 worth for $10... can't beat that.  This place is a bit like the store LUSH, but definitley at a better price point.  Not as much variety, they have shampoo bars, bath bombs, sugar scrubs, body wash, lotions and bar soaps.  Didn't appear to be any facial products or hair conditioners.
